newsitem.title: UK: Venture capitalists back Virgin Rail.
newsitem.headline: Venture capitalists back Virgin Rail.

text.p: British entrepreneur Richard Branson's Virgin Group said on Wednesday a group of financial institutions are backing its move into running some of Britain's railways and thereore there was no need for a share flotation for its new rail subsidiary.

Virgin director Will Whitehorn told Reuters that Bankers Trust New York Corp, Texas Pacific Group, J.P. Morgan and Electra Fleming have together invested 40 million pounds in new subsidiary Virgin Rail Group Ltd. He said this gives them an initial stake of around 40 percent but they also carry certain convertible options, which he declined to detail.
Virgin Group itself has invested a total of around 20 million pounds so far in the new venture but retains the controlling stake of around 60 percent, he added.
Branson was awarded the 15-year franchise to operate Britain's InterCity West Coast(ICWC) rail services between London and Scotland today, adding to its Cross Country franchise awarded last November.
Virgin Rail Group said it intends to acquire 80 new trains for the two networks worth around 800 million pounds, including 600 million pounds on 40 high-speed tilt trains for the West Coast Mainline.

Whitehorn said the new trains were likely to be leased rather than bought outright but Virgin Rail was also planning to spend a further 200 million pounds on improvements to services and infrastrucuture over the course of the 15-year franchises.
Whitehorn said financing for the new investments would come out of operating income.
